div.head: The family of love.
div.p: Acted by the children of his majesty's revels.
Lectori. Sydera iungamus, facito mihi Jupiter adsit, et tibi Mercurius noster dabit omnia Saxon.
At London printed for John helms, and are to be sold in saint Dunstan's churchyard in Fleetstreet. 1608.

div.head: To the reader.
div.p: Too soon and too late, this work is published: too soon, in that it was in the press, before i had notice of it, by which means some faults may escape in the printing. Too late, for that it was not published when the general voice of the people had sealed it for good, and the newness of it made it much more desired, then at this time: for plays in this city are like wenches new fallen to the trade, only desired of your neatest gallants, whiles they are fresh: when they grow stale they must be vented by termers and country chapmen. I know not how this labour will please, sure i am it passed the censure of the stage with a general applause, now (Whether vox populi be vox dei or no) that I leave to be tried by the acute judgement of the famous six wits of the city: farewell.

list.item: Dry-fat — a merchant, a brother of the family.
Lipsalve — two gallants that only pursue city lechery.
Guggin — two gallants that only pursue city lechery.
Smelled and periwinkle. Pages to the gallants.

list.head: Women.

div.head: Prologus.
div.l: If for opinion hath not blazed his fame,
Nor expectation filled the general round,
You deem his labours slight, you both confound
Your graver judgement and his merits.
Impartial hearing fits judicious spirits ,
Nor let the fruit of many an hour fall,
By envy's tooth, or base detractions gall.
Both which are tokens of such abject spirits,
Which wanting worth, themselves hate other merits:
Or else of such, which once made great by fame,
Repine at those which seek t'attain the same.
From both we know all truer judgements free
To them our muse with blushing modesty
Patiently to her entreats their favour,
Which done, with judgement praise, or else dislike the labour.

div.head: Actus primus, scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter doctor Glister, his wife, and Maria.

sp.speaker: Glister.
sp.p: Tricks and shows; protestations with men are like tears with women, forgotten ere the cheek be dry: Gerardine is a gentleman, his lands be in statutes: 'a is not for thee nor thou for him, 'a is a gallant, and young thoughts be most unconstant.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Yet young vines yield most wine.

sp.speaker: Mistress Glist.
sp.p: But old veins the best, believe not these great breeched gallants, they love for profit, not for affection, if 'a brings thee to a fool's paradise, 'a will forsake thee.

sp.speaker: Glist.
sp.p: Which fortune, God send my enemy: love is a cold heat, a bitter sweet, a pleasure full of pain, a huge loss, and no gain, why shouldst thou love him only?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Words cannot force what destiny hath sealed,
Who can resist the influence of his stars,
Or give a reason why a love's, or hates
Since our affections are not ruled by will,
But will by our affections. 'tis blasphemy
'Gainst love's most sacred deity, to axe
Why we do love, since 'tis his only power
That sways all our affections, all things which be
Beasts, birds, men, gods, pay him their fealty

sp.speaker: Glister.
sp.p: Tut, love is an idle fantasy, bred by desire, nursed by delight, an humour that begins his dominion in Leo the lion, the sign of the heart, and ends in Aries the ram, the sign of the head, his power is to stir the blood, pricks up the flesh, fills all the body with a libidinous humour, and is indeed the overture of all ladies: which to prevent, i have banished Gerardine (Your dear beloved) my house, and as for you, since I

sp.speaker: Lyp.
sp.p: In her smile deceitful.

sp.speaker: Gug.
sp.p: In her hate revengeable.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: And in nothing but her death acceptable, I'll tell thee: there's no creature more desirous of an honest name and worse keeps it, than a woman, dost here, follow this song and if ever thou forsake thy country for a wagtail, let me be whipped to death with ladies' hair-laces.

sp.speaker: Gera.
sp.p: Let's here that worthy song gentle master Lipsalve.

sp.speaker: Lips.
sp.l: Observe? Now if I list will I love no more
Nor longer wait upon a gill.
Since every place now yields a wench
If one will not another will;
And if what I have heard be true
Then young and old, and all will do:
How dost thou like this? man.

sp.speaker: Gerar.
sp.l: No more no more,
This is the chamber which confines my love,
This is the abstract of the spacious world,
Within it holds a ge,, so rich so rare
That art or nature never yet could set
A valued prize to her in valued worth.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.l: Valued worth, ha ha ha! Why? she's but a woman,
And they are windy turning veins, love light as chaff which when
Our nourishing grains are winnowed from them,
Unconstantly they fly at the least wind of passion
A woman's eye, can turn itself with quick dexterity
And in each wanton glass can comprehend
Their sundry fancy suited to each fend
Tut their loves are all compact of levity
Even like themselves, nil muliere lenius.

sp.speaker: Gug.
sp.p: Tut man every one knows their worth, when they are at a rack rent; in the term time, they bear as great a prize as wheat when transportations are. —

sp.speaker: Gera.
sp.p: Peace let's draw near the window and listen if we may hear her.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Debarred of liberty! O that this flesh
Could like swift moving thoughts transfer itself,
from place to place, unseen and undissolved:
Then should no iron ribs, or churlish flint
Divide my love and me, dear Gerardin
Despite of chance or guardians tyranny,
Jde move within thy orb and thou in mine.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: She'd move within thy orb, and thou in hers, blood she talk bawdy to herself: Guggin stand close;

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: But in vain do I proclaim my grief,
When air and walls can yield me no relief.

sp.speaker: Gug.
sp.p: The walls are the more stony hearted then,

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Peace good gudgeon gape not so loud.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Come thou my best companion, thou art sensible
And canst my wrongs reiterate; thou and I.
Will make some mirth in spite of tyranny:
The black browed night drawn in her pithy wain
In starry spangled pride rides now o'er heaven
Now is the time when stealing minutes tell
The stole delight joyed by all faithful lovers
Now loving souls contrive both place and means,
For wished pastimes only I am pent
Within the closure of this fatal wall
Deprived of all my joys.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: My dear Maria be comforted in this?
The frame of heaven shall sooner seize to move,
Bright Phoebus' steeds leave their diurnal race
And all that is forsake their natural being
Ere I forget thy love.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Who is that protests so fast?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Thy ever vowed servant Gerardine.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: O by your vows it seems you'd fain get up

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: I and ride to.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I would most loved Maria.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I knew it: he that to get up to a fair woman
Will stick to vow and swear, may be accounted no man,
But tell me why hast thou chose this hour to visit me?
Which nor the day nor night can claim but both
Or neither, why in this twilight camest thou?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: T'avoid suspicious eyes, I come dear love
To take my last farewell, fitting this hour
Which nor bright day will claim nor pitchy night
An hour sit to part conjoined souls,
Since that my native soil will not afford
My wished and best content, I will forsake it
And prove more strange to it than it to me.
In times swift course all things shall find event
Be it good or ill, and destinies do grant
That most preposterous courses often gain,
What labour and direct proceedings miss.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Wilt thou forsake me then?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Let first blessed life forsake me, be constant
My absence may procure thy more enlarge
And then —

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Desire's conceit is quick, I apprehend thee
Be thou as loyal, as I constant prove,
And time shall knit our mutual knot of love,
Wear this my love's true pledge: I need not wish
I know thou wilt return, or will I say
Thou mayst conceal thyself being returned
Till I may make escape and visit thee.
I prithee love attempt not to ascend
My chamber window by a lathered rope?
Th' entrance is too narrow: except this post
Which may with ease, yet that is dangerous:
I pray thee do it not I here some call: farewell
My constant love let after actions tell;

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: O perfection of women!
A plague of such perfection, how she woos, by negatives shows

sp.speaker: Gug.
sp.p: Thee? what to do? under colour of dissuasion

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: She's truly virtuous.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Tut man outward appearance is no authentic instance of the inward desires, women have sharp falcons eyes, and can soar aloft, but keep them like falcons from flesh and they soon stoop to a gawdy lure.

sp.speaker: Gera.
sp.p: Why then Huguenot women are admirable angels.

sp.speaker: Gugg.
sp.p: But angels make them admirable devils.

sp.speaker: Gera.
sp.p: My love's chaste smile to all the world doth speak her spotless innocence.

sp.speaker: Lipsalve.
sp.p: Women's smiles are more of custom then of courtesy, women are creatures, their hearts and they are full of holes, apt to receive but not retain affection; thou wilt tomorrow thou saist be gone, if thou wilt know the worst of a country's marry before thou goest, for if thou canst endure a cursed wife, never care what company thou comest in.

sp.speaker: Gerar.
sp.p: Come merry gallants, will you associate me to my cousin purges the pothecaries, and take part of my parting feasts tonight .

sp.speaker: Gug.
sp.p: O his wife is of the family of love, I'll thither, perhaps I may prove of the fraternity in time, we'll thither that's flat.

div.head: Act. 1. Sena. 3.
div.p: What club, club, is club within there.

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: Mistress.

sp.speaker: Mistress Purge.
sp.p: I pray what said master doctor Glister, will 'a come.

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: 'A sent word 'a would, for 'a was but to carry a diet to one of his patients; what call you her, she that paints a day times, and looks fair and fresh, on the outside, but in the night time is filthier than the inside of Bocardo, and is indeed far more unsavoury that know her forsooth.

sp.speaker: Mistress Purge
sp.p: Went a to her.

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: 'A had a receipt for the grincomes in his hand, and a said a would take that in his way.

sp.speaker: Mistress Purge
sp.p: 'Tis well, and what guest besides him and his wife will be here at supper.

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p:
The first in my account is master Gerarine your cousin:
master doctor Glister and his wife: master Drifat the merchant, master Lipsalve the courtier, master Guggin the gallant, and their pages. These i take will be your full number.

sp.speaker: Mi purge
sp.p: Then belike my room shall be stuffed with courtiers and gallants tonight : of all men I love not these gallants, they'll prate much but do little, they are people most uncertain: they use great words, but little sense: great beards, but little wit: great breeches but no money.

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: That was the last thing they swore away.

sp.speaker: Mi purge
sp.p: Belike they cannot fetch it again with swearing, for if they could, there's not a page of theirs, but would be as rich as a monarch.

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: There's nothing mistress that is sworn out of date, that returns; their first oath in times past was by the mass: and that they have sworn quite away: then came they to their faith, as by my faith 'tis so: that in a short time was sworn away too; for no man believes now more than 'a sees. Then they swore by their honesties, and that mistress you know is sworn quite away: after their honesties was gone, then came they to their gentility, and swore, as they were gentlemen: and their gentility they swore away so fast, that they had almost sworn away all the ancient gentry out of the land, which indeed are scarce missed: for that yeomen and farmers' sons, with the help of a few Welshmen, have undertaken to supply their places. That at the last they came to silver; and their oath was, by the cross of this silver, and swore so fast upon that, that now they have scarce left them a cross for to swear by.

sp.speaker: Mistress Purge.
sp.p: And what do they swear by now their money is gone.

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: Why by () and God refuse them.

sp.speaker: Mistress Purge
sp.p: And can they not as well say men refuse them, as God refuse them.

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p:
No mistress, for men, especially citizens and rich
men, have refused them their bonds and protestations already.

sp.speaker: Mistress purge
sp.p: 'Tis well, see how supper goes forward, and that my shoes be very well blacked, against i go to the family.

Now sweet chick, where hast thou been, in troth law I am not well, i had thought to have spent the morning at the family, but now I am resolved to take pills, and therefore I pray thee desire doctor glister that 'a would minister to me, in the morning.

sp.speaker: Mast. purge
sp.l: Thy will is known, and this for answer say,
'Tis fit that wise-men should their wives obey.
sp.p: And now sweet duck know, I have been for my cousin Gerardine's will and have it, 'a has given thee a legacy, but the total is Maria's.
sp.stage: Enter master glister, master Dryfatt, and mistress glister.
sp.p: Master doctor, your wife and master dry-fat are most welcome, now were my cousin Gerardine and master Lipsalve here, our number were complete.

sp.speaker: Do. Glist.
sp.p: Is this frantic will done, will master Gerardine to sea, let me tell you I am no whit sorry, let such as will be headstrong bite on the bridle.

sp.speaker: Ma. purge.
sp.p: 'Tis here master doctor, all his worth is Maria's and locked in a trunk, which by tomorrow sun, shall be delivered to your custody.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: methinks 'twere a reasonable match to bestow your niece on master Gerardine: 'a is a most hopeful gentleman, and his revenue such, that having your nieces portion to clear it of all encumbrances, 'twill maintain them both in a very worthy degree.

sp.speaker: Doctor Glist.
sp.p:
Tut, you are master Dryfatt the merchant, your skill is greater in coney-skins and wollpacks, then in gentlemen, his lands be in statutes, you merchants were wont to be merchant staplers, but now gentlemen have gotten up the trade, for there is not one
gentleman amongst twenty but his land be engaged in twenty statutes staple.

sp.speaker: Lipsalve.
sp.l: Let every man his humour have, I do at none repine,
I never regard whose wench i kiss, nor who doth the like by mine:
Th' indifferent minds I hold still best, whatever does befall,
For she that will do with me and thee, will be a wench for all; and how goes the squares.

sp.speaker: Ma. purge
sp.p: Your stay gentleman does wrong to a great many of good stomachs, your suppers expect you.

sp.speaker: Guggin.
sp.p: And we our suppers.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: And from what good exercise come you three.

sp.speaker: Gera.
sp.p: From a play, where we saw most excellent Sampson excel the whole world in gate carrying.

sp.speaker: Dry .
sp.p: Was it performed by the youths.

sp.speaker: Lypsal.
sp.p: By youths: why I tell thee we saw Sampson, and i hope 'tis not for youths to play Sampson: believe it we saw Sampson bear the town gates on his neck, from the lower to the upper stage, with that life and admirable accord, that it shall never be equalled (Unless the whole new livery of porters set their shoulders)

sp.speaker: Mistress Purge
sp.p: Fie fie, 'tis pity young gentlemen can bestow their time no better, this playing is not lawful, for I cannot find that either plays or players were allowed in the prime church of Ephesus by the elders.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Aha, I think she tickled you there.

sp.speaker: Ma. purge.
sp.p: Cousin Gerardine, shall the will be read before supper?

sp.speaker: Gera.
sp.p: Before supper I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Lyp.
sp.p: I, ay, before supper, for when these women's bellies be full their bones will be soon at rest.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Well master doctor pity the state of a poor gentleman it is in you to stay his journey, and make him and yourself happy in his choice.

sp.speaker: Glist.
sp.p: Hold you content shall this will be read?

sp.speaker: Ma. purge.
sp.p: It shall, read you good master Lipsalve.

sp.speaker: Lyp.
sp.p: Command silence then.

sp.speaker: Gug.
sp.p: Silence.

sp.speaker: Lyp.
sp.p: In the name of God amen. Know all men by these presence, that I Gerardine being strong of body, and perfect in sense.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: That's false, there's no lover in his perfect sense.

sp.speaker: Gug.
sp.p: Peace dry-fat.

sp.speaker: Lypsal.
sp.p: Do give and grant to Maria Glister: daughter of John Glister, and niece to doctor glister physician, all my leases, lands, chattels, goods and movables whatsoever: this is stark naught, you cannot give away your movables, for mistress doctor and mistress purge, claim both shares in your movables by reason of their legacies.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: That's true, for their legacies must go out of your movables.

sp.speaker: Lyp.
sp.p: I put it in all my movables, these following legacies being paid.

sp.speaker: Gerar.
sp.p: Do so good master Lipsalve.

sp.speaker: Lyp.
sp.p: 'Tis done.

sp.speaker: Mistress Purge.
sp.p: I pray read only the legacies, for supper stays.

sp.speaker: Lyp.
sp.p: Well, the legacies, first I give to my cousin mistress purge a fair large standing, what's this, oh cup; a fair large standing cup, with a close stool.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: 'Tis not so, 'tis not so.

sp.speaker: Lyp.
sp.p: I cry you mercy, a close cover 'tis, to mistress doctor I give a fair bodkin of gold, with two orient pearls attending the same: all which are in my trunk to be delivered to the keeping of Maria, in witness, etc. Is this your will?

sp.speaker: Gerar.
sp.p: 'Tis.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: To it with your hand and seal.

sp.speaker: Mistress Purge.
sp.p: How is it chick, I must have the standing cup, and mistress glister the bodkin.

sp.speaker: Mast. purge .
sp.p: Right sweet duck.

sp.speaker: Gerar.
sp.p: I pray gentlemen put to your hands.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Come, your fists gentlemen your fists.

sp.speaker: Gerar.
sp.p: Mistress Glister, I have found you always more flexible to understand the estate of a poor gentleman, than your husband was willing, therefore I have thought it a point of charity to reveal the wrongs you sustained by your husband's looseness. Let me tell you in private, that the doctor cuckolds purgo oftener than he visits one of his patients: what 'a spares from you, 'a spends lavishly on her: these pothecaries are a kind of panders, look to it, if 'a keep Maria long close, it is for some lascivious end of his own.

sp.speaker: Mi Gli.
sp.p: She is his niece.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Tut, these doctors have tricks, your niceness is such, that you can endure no polluted shows in your house, take heed lest 'a make you a bawd before your time, look to it.

sp.speaker: Lipsalve.
sp.p: Come, our hands are testimonies to thy follies, shall's now to supper, we'll have a health go round to thy voyage.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: I and to all that forswear marriage, and can be content with other men's wives.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Of which consort you two are grounds, one touches
The base, and the other tickles the minikin.
But to our cheer, come gentles let's away,
The roastmeat's in consumption by our stay.

div.head: Actus secundus, scaena prima.
div.p:
The grey eyed morning braves me to my face, and calls me sluggard, 'tis time for tradesmen to be in their
shops, for he that tends well his shop, and hath an alluring wife, with a graceful what de lack, shall be sure to have good doings, and good doings is that, that crowns so many citizens, with the horns of abundance. My wife (By ordinary course) should this morning have been at the family, but now her soft pillow hath given her counsel to keep her bed, master doctor should (Indeed) minister to her: to whose pills she is so much accustomed, that now her body looks for them as duly, as the moon shakes off the old, and borrows new horns. I smile to myself to hear our knights and gallants say, how they gull us citizens, when indeed we gull them, or rather, they gull themselves: here they come (In term time,) higher chambers, and perhaps kiss our wives: well: what lose I by that: God's blessing on's heart I say still, that makes much of my wife, for they were very hard favoured, that none could find in's heart to love but ourselves: drugs would be dog cheap but for my private well practised doctor, and such customers. Tut, jealousy is a hell, and they that will thrive, must utter their wares as they can, and wink at small faults.

sp.speaker: Glist.
sp.p: The tedious night is past, and the jocund morn looks more lively and fresh, than an old gentlewoman's glazed face in a new periwig; by this time my humorous lover is at Gravesend, and i go with more joy to fetch his trunk, than ever the valiant Trojans did to draw in the Grecian jade, his goods shall into the walls of my Troy, and be offered to a face more lively, then ever was that thrice ravished Helen, yet with such caution, that no danger shall happen to me.

div.stage: Lypsalue and Gudgin at several doors, with their pages, shrimp and Periwinde.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Master Lipsalve, welcome within ken, we two are so nearly linked, that if thou beest absent but one two hours, thy acquaintance grows almost mouldy in my memory.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: And then fly blown in mine how dost thou do.

sp.speaker: Shrim.
sp.p: Fellow page, I think our acquaintance runs low to, but if it run not of the lees, let's set it a tilt, and give 'em some dregs to their mouldy fly blown compliments.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.p: No rather let's pierce the roundlets of our running heads and give 'em a neat cup of wagship, to put down their courtship.

sp.speaker: Shr.
sp.p: Courtship, cartship: for the tongues of complementers run on wheels: but mark 'em they ha' not done yet.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: And i'faith how is't: methinks thou hast been a long vagrant.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: The rogation hath been long indeed: therefore we may salute as ceremoniously as lawyers when they meet after a long vacation, who to renew the discontinud state tale, they stretch it out with such length, that whilst they greet before, their clients kiss them behind.

sp.speaker: Shr.
sp.p: If his nose were put i'the remainder of that state tale, he would say 'twere an unsavoury one.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.p: I wonder why many men gird so at the law.

sp.speaker: Shr.
sp.p: I'll tell thee, because they themselves have neither law nor conscience.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: But what news now? how stands the state of things at Brussels.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Faith weak and limber, weak and limber: nothing but pride and double dealing, virtue is vice's lackey; beggars suck like horse leeches at the heart of bounty, and love's theme so tired and spurgald, that he can be no longer ridden with honesty.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Well fare the city yet: there virtue rides a cockhorse cherished and kept warm in good sables, and fox fur, and with the breath of his nostrils, drives pride and covetousness before him, like's own shadow: beggars have whipping cheer, bounty obliges men to't, gives money for scrips and scrolls, and liberality sealed with strong arms and heraldry, to out live mortality: love there will see the last man born, never give over while there's an arrow i'th quiver.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Now we talk of love, I do know not far hence so good a subject for that humour, that if she would wear but the standing colour, and her things in fashion, our ladies in the court were but brown sugarcandy, as gross as grocery to her.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: She is not so sweet as a potticary's shop is she?

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: A plague on you, ha' you so good a sent? for my life he's my rival.

sp.speaker: Gudgin.
sp.p: Her name begins with mistress purge does it not?

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: True, the only comet of the city.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Ay, if she would let her ruffs stream out a little wider; but i am sure she is ominous to me, she makes civil wars and insurrections in the state of my stomach: i had thought to have bound myself from love, but her purging comfits makes me lose bodied still.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: What has she ministered to thee then?

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Faith some lectuary or so.

sp.speaker: Lipsalve.
sp.p: I, I fear she takes too much of that lectuary to stoop to love, it keeps her body soluble from sin, she is not troubled with carnal crudities, nor the binding of the flesh.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Thou hast sounded her then belike.

sp.speaker: Lypsalue.
sp.p: Not I: I am too shallow to sound her, she's out of my element, if I show passion, and discourse of love to her, she tells me I am wide from the right scope, she says she has another object, and aims at a better love than mine.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: O that's her husband.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: No, no, she speaks pure devotion, she's impenetrable, no gold, or oratory, no virtue in herbs, nor no physic will make her love.

sp.speaker: Gudgin.
sp.p: More is the pity I say, that fair women should prove saints, before age had made them crooked: 'tis my luck to be crossed still, but I must not give over the chase.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Come hither boy while I think on't.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Faith friend Lipsalve I perceive you would fain play with my love, a pure creature 'tis, for whom I have sought every angle of my brain: but either she scorns courtiers (As most of them do, because, they are given to boast of their doings) or else she's exceeding straight laced: therefore to prevent this smell smock, I'll to my friend doctor Glister, (A man exquisite in th' art magic) who hath told me of many rare experiments available in this case: farewell friend Lipsavle.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Adieu honest Gregorio, frequent my lodging, i have a viol de gamba and good tobacco: thou wilt do this feat boy?

sp.speaker: Shr.
sp.p: Else knock my head and my pate together,

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Away then bid him bring his measure with him: Gerardine is travelled, and I must needs be cast into his mould: my flesh grows proud; and Maria's a sweet wench, etc. But yet I must not let fall my suit with mistress purge, lest (Cede vacanti) my friend gudgeon join issue: I'll rather to my learned doctor for a spell, for i have a fire in my liver, burns like hell.

sp.speaker: Mistress Glist.
sp.p: I pray let's have no polluted feet nor rheumatic chaps enter the house, I shall have my flower look more greasy shortly, than one of your inn of court dining tables: and now to you good niece I bend my speech, let me tell you plainly, you are a fool to be lovesick for any man, longer than he is in your company, are you so ignorant in the rules of courtship, to think any one man to bear all the prick and praise? I tell thee, be he never so proper, there is another to second him.

sp.speaker: Ma .
sp.l: Let rules of courtship be authentic still,
to such as do pursue variety,
But unto those whose modest thoughts do tend.
To honoured nuptials, and a regular life
As far from show of niceness, as from that
Of impure thoughts, all other objects seem
Respectless, of no proportion balanced with esteem
Of what their souls affect.

sp.speaker: Mistress Glist.
sp.p: No marvel sure you should regard these men with such reverend opinion, there's few good faces, and fewer graces in any of them, if one among a multitude have a good pair of legs, he never leaves riding the ring, till he has quite marred the proportion: nay some (As I have heard) wanting lineaments to their liking, and calf to support themselves, are fain to use art, and supply themselves with quilted calves, which oftentimes in revelling fall about their ankles, and for their behaviour, wit and discourse (Except some few that are travelled) it is as imperfectious and silly, as your scholars new come from the university, by this light I think we lose part of our happiness when we make these weathercocks our equals.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Disgrace not that for which our sect was made,
Society in nuptial beds above these joys
Which lovers taste, when their conjoined lips
Suck forth each others souls, the earth the air,
Yea gods themselves know none: Elysium's sweet
I all that bliss which poets pens describe
Are only known, when soft and amorous folds,
Entwine the corpse of two united lovers,
Where what they wish, they have yet still desire,
And sweets are known without society.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.p: Here's club forsooth and his fellow prentice have brought master Gerardine's trunk.

sp.speaker: Mistress Glist.
sp.p: Let them come in if their feet be clean.

So then your best beloved is gone, fair weather after him; all thy passions go with him, recomfort thyself wench in a better choice, his love to thee would have been of no longer continuance
than the untrussing of his hose, then why shouldst thou pine for such a one.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: She's foolish sure, with what imperfect phrase,
And shallow wit she answers me.

div.stage: Enter Club and another with the trunk.

sp.speaker: Mistress Gli.
sp.p: Honest club welcome, is this master Gerardine's trunk? he is gone then?

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: I indeed mistress Glister, he is departed this transitory city, but his whole substance is here enclosed, which (By command) we here deliver to your custody, to the use of mistress Maria according to the tenure of the premises.

sp.speaker: Mi Gli.
sp.p: Place it here my honest club, well done: and how does thy mistress . was she at the family today, — spit not good club, i can not abide it.

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: Not today forsooth, she hath overcharged herself and her memory, she means to use a moderation, and take no more than she can make use of.

sp.speaker: Mi Gli.
sp.p: And I pray thee club what kind of creatures are these Familists, thou art conversant with them.

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: What are they? With reverence be it spoken, they are the most accomplished creatures under heaven, in them is all perfection.

sp.speaker: Mi Gli.
sp.p: As how good club?

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: Omitting their outward graces, I'll show you only one instance which includes all other: they love their neighbours better than themselves.

sp.speaker: Mi Gli.
sp.p: Not than themselves club.

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: Yes better than themselves, for they love them beter than their husbands, and husband and wife are all one; therefore better than themselves.

sp.speaker: Mi Glist.
sp.p: This is logic. But tell me doth she not endeavour to bring my doctor of her side and fraternity.

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: Let him resolve that himself for here he comes.

sp.speaker: Do. Gli.
sp.p: O: hast thou brought the trunk honest club, I commend thy honest care, here's for thy pains.

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: I thank you master doctor, you are free and liberal still, you'll command me nothing back?

sp.speaker: Doct. Glist.
sp.p: Nothing but commendations, farewell: your sweet heart Gerardine is by this time cold of his hope to enjoy thee: he's gone, and a more equal and able husband shall my care ere long provide thee: what clients have been here in my absence wife?

sp.speaker: Mi Glist.
sp.p: Faith mouse none that I know, more than an old woman that had lost her cat, and came to you for a spell in the recovery.

sp.speaker: Doctor Glist.
sp.p: I think egregious ignorance will go near to save this age, their blindness takes me for a conjurer: yesterday a justice of peace salutes me, with proffer of a brace of angels to help him to his foot-cloth, some 3. days before stolen, and was fain to use his man's cloak in stead on't.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.p: Here's a gentleman craves speech with you sir.

sp.speaker: Do. Gli.
sp.p: Go in sweet wife, and give my niece good counsel: his name.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.p: He will not tell it me.

sp.speaker: Do. Glist.
sp.p: His countenance.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.p: I can see nothing but his eyes; the rest of him is so rapt in cloak, that it suffers no view.

sp.speaker: Do. Glist.
sp.p: Admit him, what should he be for a man: what master Lipsalve is't you? why thus obscured, what discontent overshadows you.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: A discontent indeed master doctor, which to shake off, i must have you extend your art to the utmost bounds: you physicians are as good as false doors behind hangings to ladies necessary uses: you know the very hour in which they have neither will to deny, nor wit to mistrust: faith now by the way, when are women most apt.

sp.speaker: Do. Gli.
sp.p: Shall I unbutton myself unto you; after the receipt of a purgation . for then are their pores most open: but what creature of a courtier is it, hath drawn your head into the woodcock's noose.

sp.speaker: Lyp.
sp.p: A courtier? nay by this flesh, i am clean fallen out with them, they have nothing proportionable.

sp.speaker: Do. Glist.
sp.p: O I perceive then 'tis some city star that attracts your aspect.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: He knows by his art — in plain terms a certain pothecaries wife.

sp.speaker: Do. Glist.
sp.p: Upon my life master purge, I smell you sir.

sp.speaker: Lyp.
sp.p: You may smell a man after a purgation indeed: sir, 'tis she: now for that same hath bruited you to be a man expert in negromancy, I would endeavour myself to you for ever, would you vouchsafe to let one of your spirits bring mistress purge into some convenient place, where I might enjoy her: I have heard of the like, can you perform this.

sp.speaker: Do. Gli.
sp.p: With much facility I assure you: but you must understand, that the apparition of a spirit is dreadful, and with all covetous, and with no small sum of gold hired to such feats.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.p: Sir here's another gentleman muffled too, that desires present conference with you.

sp.speaker: Doct. Glist.
sp.p: Walk you into that room, I will bethink myself for your good, and instantly resolve you; let the gentleman come in: Lipsalve in love with my vessel of ease? come to me to help him to a morsel most affected by mine own palate? No more but so, I have shaped it, the conceit tickles me.
Sir, as a stranger i welcome you, what master gudgeon have i caught you: i thought it was a gallant that walked muffled, come, let me behold you at full, here are no sergeants man.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Master doctor, this my obscure coming requires an action more obscure: and in brief this 'tis; sir, you are held a man far seen in nature's secrets, I know you can effect many things almost impossible; know than I love mistress purge, and opportunity favours me not, nor indeed is she so tractable as I expected, if either by medicine, or your art magical, you can work her to my will, i have a poor gallants reward sir.

sp.speaker: Doct, Glist.
sp.p: That's just nothing. But how sir would you have me to procure you access to mistress purge, you never knew a physician a bawd.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Why by conjuration (I tell you) wherein you are said to be as well practised, as in physic; here's the best part of my present store to effect it.

sp.speaker: Do. Glist.
sp.p: Not a penny for myself, but my spirits indeed they must be fed; walk you by here, while I think upon a spell. What mystery should this be, Lipsalve and gudgeon both in love with mistress purge, and come to me to help 'em by art magic? 'tis some gullery sure; yet if my invention hold, I'll fit them:Enter one.who's within there, fetch me in all haste two good whips, I think you may have them not far hence; it shall be so, now tell me master gudgeon does no man know of your love to mistress purge:

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Not a man by my gentry.

sp.speaker: Do. Glist.
sp.p: Then sir know I'll effect it; but understand withal, the apparition will be most horrid, if it appear in his proper form, and will so amaze and dull your senses, that your appetite will be lost and weak, though mistress purge should attend it naked now sir, could you name a friend with whom you are most conversant, in his likeness should the spirit appear.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Of all men living, my conversation is most frequent with Lipsalve the courtier.

sp.speaker: Doct. Gli.
sp.p: 'Tis enough: I'll to my spirit — are these whips come there?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Ready here sir.

sp.speaker: Doct. Glist.
sp.p:
So lie thou there; my noble gallants I'll so firk you: sir my spirit agrees in lipsalve's shape; tomorrow twixt the hours of four and five, shall mistress purge be rapt with a whirlwind into lipsalve's chamber, that's the fittest place: for by the break of day Lipsalve shall be mounted, and forsake the city for three days, so my spirit resolves me : now sir, by my art, at that very hour shall his chamber door fly open,
into which boldly enter in this sort accoutered: put me on a pure clean shirt, leave off your doublet, (For spirits endure nothing polluted) take me this whip in your hand, and being entered you shall see the spirit in lipsalve's shape, in the self same form that you appear; speak these words here ready written, take three bold steps forward, then whip him soundly, who straight vanisheth and leaves mistress purge to your will.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: I but shall your spirit come armed with a whip too?

sp.speaker: Do. Glist.
sp.p: He shall, but have no power to strike.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Is this infallible, have you seen the proof?

sp.speaker: Do. Glist.
sp.p: Probatum upon my word, I have seen the experience, if it fail, say I am a fool, and no magician.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Master doctor I would you had some suit at court, by the faith of a courtier, i would beg it for you: fare you well sir, I shall report of you, as I find your charm.

sp.speaker: Doct. Glist.
sp.p: And no otherwise sir; let me understand how you thrive: ha, ha, ha, now to my friend Lipsalve, I must possess him with the same circumstance, wherein i am assured to get perpetual laughter in their follies, and my revenge.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: O which way shall i turn, or shift, or go,
To lose one thought of care, no soothing hope
Gives intermission, or beguiles one hour
Of tedious time, which never will have end,
Whilst love pursues, in vain my absent friend,
Thou continent of wealth, whose want of store
For that it could not poise th'unequal scale
Of avarice givest matter to my moan,
Oh dross the level of insatiate eyes
The devil's engine, and the soul's corrupter,
Thou playst th' attorney 'gainst the lawful force
Of true affection, dost interpose a bar,
Twixt hearts conjoined: cursed be thy seed of strife,
whose progress chokes the natural course of life.

div.stage: Gerardine rising out of the trunk, she seems fearful, and flies.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: O help, help, help.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Stay sweet Maria, I bring thee ample joy
To check that sudden fear, let thy sweet heart
That constant seat of thy affection,
Repay that blood exhausted from thy veins;
Fear not sweet wench? I am no apparition,
But the firm substance of thy truest friend,
Know'st thou me now?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Gerardine my love?
What unheard of accident presents
Thy unexpected self, and gives my heart
Matter of joy, mixed with astonishment.
I thought thou hadst been cabined in thy ship.
Not trunked within my cruel guardian's house.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: That cruelty gives fuel to desire,
For love suppressed fares like a raging fire
Which burns all obstacles that stop his course,
And mounts aloft; the ocean in his source
May easier hide himself, and be confined,
Then love can be obscured; for in the mind,
She holds her seat, and through that heavenly essence,
Is near, when far remote; her virtual presence,
Fills (Like the air) all places, gives delight,
Hope in despair and heart, 'gainst fell despite.
That worst of men thy cruel guardian may
Keep down a while, but cannot dissipate
What heaven hath joined, for fate and providence,
Gave me this stratagem, to let him know,
That love will creep, where 'tis restrained to go.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I apprehend the rest: oh rare conceit,
I see thy travel happily was feigned
To win access, which with small ease thou hast gained:
This trunk, which he so greedily supposes,
contains thy substance (As it doth indeed)
Upon thy fair pretence, in lieu of love
Bequeathed to me, if death should stop the course,
This trunk (I say) he hugs; sink thou or swim,
So he may feed his wolf, that root of sin;
His avarice but heaven (That mocks man's might
Gives this close means t' insist upon our right.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Ingenious spirit, true oracle of love,
Thou hast prevented me, this was my plot,
Whose end and scope I long to imitate,
With accents free, and uncontrolled with fear,
Does opportunity stand fair?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Not now,
Danger stands centinel.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Then I'll retire,
We must be cautilous.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: So so, and time
Shall not oft turn his hour glass ere I'll find,
Peace and occasion fitting to thy mind.

div.head: Actus tertius scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: The coast is clear, and Argus wakeful eyes
Securely sleep: time turns to us his front;
Come sweet Maria of th' auspicious hours
Let's take advantage.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: With all my heart, i do embrace the motion with thyself:
Welcome sweet friend to liberty of air,
Which now methinks doth promp our breathes to move
Sweet accents of delight, the joys of love:
How dost thou brook thy little ease, thy trunk?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: That trunk confines this chest, this chest contains
th' unbounded speculation of our love
Incomprehensible: grief, joy, hope, and fears
(Affections of my mind) are like the spheres,
Which in their jarring motions do agree,
Through th' influence of love's sweet harmony.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Are not inferior bodies here on earth,
Produced and governed by those heavenly ones?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: They are.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: They jar (You say) yet in that strife maintain
Perpetual league: why should their influence
In rational souls be checked by erring sense?
Or why should mutual love (Confirmed by heaven)
B'infringed by men, methinks 'tis most uneven.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Thou arguest well Maria: and this withal
That bruits, nor animals do prove a thrall
To such servility: souls that are wards
To gold opinion, or th' undue regards
Of broking men, wolves that in sheepskin bands,
Pray on the hearts to join th' unwilling hands,
Ruin fair stocks, when generous houses die,
Or propagate their name with bastardy.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Sterility and barrenness ensue,
Such forced love: nor shall erroneous men
Pervert my settled thoughts, or turn mine eye
From thy fair object, which I will pursue,
Rich in thy love, proud of this interview.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I'll suck these accents, let our breathes engender
A generation of such pleasing sounds,
To interchange delights: oh my blood's on fire,
Sweet let me give more scope to true desire.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: What wouldst thou more than our minds firm contract?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Tut words are wind : thought unreduct to art,
Is but an embryon in the truest sense.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I am unvalued I had need of sense,
You make me blush: play fair yet above board:

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Hear me exemplify loves Latin word
Together with thyself
as thus: hearts joined amore: take a from thence,
Then more is the perfect moral sense,
Plural in manners, which in thee do shine
Saintlike, immortal, spotless and divine.
Take m away, o'er in beauty's name,
Craves an eternal trophy to thy fame,
Lastly take o, in re stands all my rest,
Which I in Chaucer style do term a jest.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: You break all modest bounds, away, away?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: So when men come behind, do women say.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Come come, I say

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I that's the word indeed,
Men that come bold before, are like to speed.
sp.stage: Enter Lipsalve and Shrimp his page.
sp.p: But who comes here? monstrum horrendum, my nostrils have the rank scent of knavery, Maria let's remove ourselves to the window, and observe this piece of man's flesh.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Now mistress Maria ward yourself, if my strong hope fail not, I shall be with you to bring.

sp.speaker: Shr.
sp.p: To bring what sir? some more o'your kind.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Faith boy that's mine aim.

sp.speaker: Shr.
sp.p: I'll be sworn sir, you have a good loose, you let fly at them a pace.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: I have shot fair and far off, but now I hope to hit the mark indeed.

sp.speaker: Shrim.
sp.p: God save it.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: But where's the sign?

sp.speaker: Shr.
sp.p: Why there.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: That's a special thing to be observed.

sp.speaker: Shr.
sp.p: I have heard talk of the gemini, methinks that should be a star favourable to your proceeding.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: The gemini, oh I apprehend thee: that's because i am so like Gerardine, ha is't not so boy?

sp.speaker: Shr.
sp.p:
As if you were spit out on's mouth sir, you must needs be like him, for you are both cut out of a piece: but lord sir,
how you hunt this chase of love, are you not weary?

sp.speaker: Lipsalve.
sp.p: Indefatigable boy, indefatigable.

sp.speaker: Shr.
sp.p: Fatigable (Quoth you) you may call it leaneable well enough, for i am sure it is able to make a man lean.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: 'Tis my vocation boy, we must never be weary of well doing, love's as proper to a courtier, as preciseness to a Puritan.

sp.speaker: Shr.
sp.p: Love (Subbandy lust) a punk in this place subintelligitur.

sp.speaker: Lypsalue.
sp.p: Boy I have spied my saint.

sp.speaker: Shr.
sp.p: Then down on your knees.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Fly of, lest she take thee for my familiar: save thee sweet Maria, nay wonder not (For thou thyself art wonder,) to see this unexpected gratulation.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Whom do I see? O how my senses wander?
Am not I hero: art not thou Leander?

sp.speaker: Gerar.
sp.p: Thar't in the right sweet wench more of that vain;

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.l: Her passion overcomes her, 'tis the kindest soul:
Oh excellent device; it works, it works boy.

sp.speaker: Shr.
sp.p: It dos in deed sir, like the suds of an alefat, or a washing bowl.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Joy not too much, extremes are perilous.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: O weather beaten love: Cisley go make a fire?
Go fetch my ladder of ropes, Leander's come.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Mark how prettily in her rapture she harps upon Gerardine's travel, let th'ectasy have end for I am Gerardine.

sp.speaker: Gerar.
sp.p: The devil you are.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Ha? let me see, my love so soon returned.

sp.speaker: Lyp.
sp.l: I never travelled farther than thine eyes,
My bruited journey was a happy project,
To cast a mist before thy jealous guardian,
Who now suspectless, gives some hope t'attain
My wisht delight, before pursued in vain.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Ask if he strained not hard for that same project.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Has not that project overracked thy brain.
And spent more wit than thou hast left behind.

sp.speaker: Shrimp.
sp.p: By this light she flouts him.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.l: No, wit is infinite I spent some brain;
Thy love did stretch my wit upon the tenters

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Then is't like to shrink in the wetting.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It cottons well, it cannot choose but bear
A pretty nap; I tender thy capacity,
A comfortable caudle cherish it:
But where's my favour that I bid thee wear
As pledge of love.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Now dost thou put him to't,
More tenters for his wit, he's nonplus quite

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.l: I wear it sweet Maria but on high days,
Preserve it from the taynting of the air,
What should i say: 'tis in my tother hose.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: How in your tother hose? he that i love
Shall wear my favour in those hose he has on.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Fiends and furies: block that I am.

sp.speaker: Shrim.
sp.p: In your tother hose? she talked of a ladder of ropes; if she would let it down; for my life he would hang himself in't: in your tother hose? why those hose are in lavender, besides, they have never a codpiece: but indeed there needs no ivy where the wine is good. In your tother hose?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: I said you were too prodigal of wit.

sp.speaker: Lyp.
sp.l: Expostulate no more, grant me access,
Or else I'll travel to the wilderness.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Your only way, go travel till you tire,
Be rid, and let a gull discharge the higher.

sp.speaker: Shr.
sp.p: Master, the doctor the doctor.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Where? which way.

sp.speaker: Shrim.
sp.p: This way, that way, some way I heard him coming.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: O boy i am abused, gulled, disgraced, my credit's cracked.

sp.speaker: Shr.
sp.p: You know that's nothing for a new courtier.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: O I shall run beside myself.

sp.speaker: Shr.
sp.p: No sir, that's my office, I'll run by your side.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: My brain is out of temper, what shall i do?

sp.speaker: Shr.
sp.p: Take her council sir, get a cullis to your capacity, a restorative to your reason, and a warming pan to your wit: he comes he comes.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Follow close boy, let him not see us.

sp.speaker: Doct. Glist.
sp.p: What more flatterers about my carrion? more battery to my walls? shall I never be rid of these petronel flashes? As for my friend Gerardine, the wind of my rage has blown him to discover countries, and let the sea purge his love away and him together, I care not: young wenches now are all o'the hoy: we that are guardians must respect more besides titles, gold lace, person, or parts, we must have lordships and manors, elsewhere as well as in the man: wealth commands all, and wealth I'll have, or else my minion shall lead apes in hell. I must after this gallant too, I'll know his rendezvous, and what company he keeps.

sp.speaker: Ma:
sp.l: Now must we be abrupt; retire sweet friend
To thy small ease; what more remains to do,
We'll consummate at our next interview.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: So shall i bear my prisonment with pleasure,
Look thou but big or cruel, foe will yield,
And give to Hymen the honour of the field.

div.stage: Enter mistress Purge, and Club before her with a link.

sp.speaker: Mistress Purge.
sp.p: Fie fie club, go a tother side the way, thou collowst me and my ruff, thou wilt make me an unclean member i'the congregation,

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: If you be unclean mistress, you may pure yourself, you have my master's ware at your commandment, but what am I then, that does all the drudgery in your house.

sp.speaker: Mi purge
sp.p: Thou'rt born to't, why boy I can show thy indentures thou givest no other milk: we know how to use all i' their kind.

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p:
Y' are my better in bark and rind, but in pith and
substance I may compare with you: you're above fish or flesh mistress, and there's your boast, but in my tother part, we are all one before God.

sp.speaker: Mi purge
sp.p: All one with me! dost thou swear too? why then up and ride.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Whither away mistress purge?

sp.speaker: Mi purge
sp.p: To the family master dry-fat to our exercise.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: What by night?

sp.speaker: Mi purge
sp.p: O lord, I sir, with the candles out too, we fructify best i'th dark, the glance of the eye is a great matter, it leads us to other objects besides the right.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Indeed I think we perform those functions best, when we are not thrall to the fetters of the body.

sp.speaker: Mi purge
sp.p: The fetters of the body, what call you them?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: The organs of the body, as some term them.

sp.speaker: Mi purge
sp.p: Organs: fie, fie, they have a most abominable squeaking sound in mine ears, they edify not a whit I detest hem: I hope my body has no organs.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: To speak more familiarly mistress purge, they are the senses: the sight, hearing, smelling, taste, and feeling.

sp.speaker: Mistress Purge
sp.p: I marry: (Marry said i lord what a word's that in my mouth) you speak now master dry-fat: but yet let me tell you where you err too: this feeling I will prove to be neither organ nor fetter, it is a thing (A sense did you call it?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Ay, a sense.

sp.speaker: Mistress Purge
sp.p: Why then a sense let it be (I say it is that we cannot be without: for (As I take it) it is a part belonging to understanding; understanding (You know) lifteth up the mind from earth; if the mind be lift up, you know the body goes with it: also it descends into the conscience, and there tickles us with our works and doings: so that we make singular use of feeling.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: And not of the rest?

sp.speaker: Mi purge
sp.p: Not at that time; therefore we hold it not amiss to put out the candles, for the soul sees best it'h dark.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: You come to me now mistress purge.

sp.speaker: M. Purge
sp.p: Nay i will come to you else master dry-fat: those senses (As you term them) are of much efficacy in carnal mixtures, that is, when we crowd and thrust a man and a woman together.

div.stage: Enter Purge and over hears them.

sp.speaker: Purge
sp.p: What so close at it: I thought this was one end of your exercise. By’r lady I think there is small profit in this, I'll wink no more for I am now tickled with a conceit that it is a scurvy thing to be a cuckold.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: I commend this zeal in you mistress purge, i desire much to be of your society.

sp.speaker: M. Purge
sp.p: Do you indeed, blessing on your heart: are you upright in your dealings?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Yes, i do love to stand to any thing I do, though i lose by it, in truth i deal but too truly for this world: you shall hear how far I am entered in the right way already: first I live in charity and give small alms to such as be not of the right sect. I take under twenty i'th hundred, nor no forfeiture of bonds unless the law tell my conscience I may do't, I set no pot on a Sundaies, but feed on cold meat dressed a Satterdayes, I keep no holy days, nor fasts, but eat most flesh o'frydayes of all days i'the week: i do use to say inspired graces able to starve a wicked man with length, I have Aminadab's and Abrams to my god sons, and I chide them when they ask me blessing: and I do hate the red letter, more than i follow the written verity.

sp.speaker: Purge.
sp.p: Here's clergy.

sp.speaker: Mi purge
sp.p: These are the rudiments indeed master dry-fat.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Nay I can tell you I am or will be of the right stamp.

sp.speaker: Purge
sp.p: A pox o'your stamp.

sp.speaker: Mi purge
sp.p: Then learn the word for your admittance, and you will be much made on by the congregation.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: I the word good mistress purge.

sp.speaker: Mi purge
sp.p: A brother in the family.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Enough i have my lesson.

sp.speaker: Purge
sp.p: So have I mine, a brother in the family, I must be a familist today. I'll follow this gear while 'tis on foot i'fath.

sp.speaker: Mi purge
sp.p: Then shore up your eyes, and lead the way to the goodliest people that ever turned up the white o'th eye, give me my book club, put out thy link, and come behind us.

sp.speaker: Answer within.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Two brothers and a sister in the family — let in.

sp.speaker: — Within
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Purge.
sp.p: A familiar brother.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Here's no room for you nor your familiarity.

sp.speaker: Purge
sp.p:
How? no room for me nor my familiarity? why what's the difference between a familiar brother, and a brother in the family? O I know: i made eclipses of in, in this place where it should have been expressed, so that the want of in, put me clean out; or let me see: may it not be some mystery drawn from arithmetic? For my life these Familists love no substraction, take nothing away, but put in and add as much as you will, and after addition follows multiplication of a most pharasithipocritical crew. Well for my part I like not this family, nor indeed some kind of private lecturing that women use: look to't, you that have such gadders to your wives: self willed they are as children, and i'faith capable of not much more than they peevish by custom, naturally fools. I remember a pretty wooden sentence in a preamble to an exercise, where the reader prayed: that men of his coat might grow up like cedars to make good wainscot in the house of sincerity, would not this wainscot phrase be writ in brass, to publish him that spoke it for an animal: why, such wooden pellets out of earthen trunks, do strike these females into admiration, hits 'em home, sometimes (Perhaps) in at one ear, and out at tother, and then they depart in opinion, wiser than their neighbours, fraught with matter, able to take down and mortify their husbands. Well I'll home now, and bring the true word next time: I shall expect my wife anon red hot with zeal, and big with melting tears; and this night do I expect, (As her manner is) she will weep me a whole chamberpot full, loquor lapides? do i cast pills abroad? 'tis no matter what I
say, i talk like a pothecary (As I am) I have only purged myself of a little choler and passion, and am now armed with a patient resolution, but how? to put my horns in my pocket? no:
sp.l: What wise men bear is not for me to scorn,
'Tis a honourable thing to wear the horn.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Fortune, devil's turd i'thy teeth, I'll turn no more o'thy wheel, art is above thy might: what though my project with mistress Maria failed, more ways to the wood than one, there's variety in love. It is believed I am out of town, my door is open, the hour is at hand, all things squared by the doctor's rule, and now I look for the spirit to bring me warm comfort, to clothe my nakedness, and that is mistress purge, the cordial of a Familist, and come quickly good spirit, or else my teeth will chatter for thee.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: O the naked pastimes of love, the scourge of dulness, the purifier of uncleanness, and the hot house of humanity: I have taken physic of master purge, any time this twelve months to purge my humour upon's wife, and i have ever found her so fugitive, from exercise to exercise, and from family to family, that I could never yet open the close stool of my mind to her: so that I may well say with Ovid: hei mihi quod nullus amor est medicabilis herbis: now am i driven to prove the violent virtue conjuration, if it hit, and that I yearke my familist out of the spirit, I'll hang up my scourge-stick for a trophy, and imparadise my thoughts, though the doctor go to the devil, 'tis no matter: ha let me see; Lipsalve's door open! and himself out of town? excellent doctor, soothsaying doctor, oraculous doctor.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p:
I have taken up this standing to see my gallants play at barriers with scourge-sticks for the honour of my punk: and in good time I see my brave spirits shining in bright armour
nakedly burning in the hell fire of lechery, and ready for the hot encounter: sound trumpets, the combatants are mounted.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: The apparition: mistress purge peers through him, I see her.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: The spirit appears: but he might have come sooner: I am numbed with cold, a shivering ague hath taken away my courage.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: They are afraid one of another, look how they tremble, the flesh and the devil strengthen 'em: ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Has 'a no cloven feet, what a laxative fever shakes me.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Will a not carry me with him to hell? well I must venture: Clogmathos

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: My cue: Clogmathathos.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: My cue Garrazin.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Garragas.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Garrazinos.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Tun tetuphon.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Taes tetuphes.

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.p: With a Whirley Twinos — they lash one another.

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.p: Hold, hold, hold, gog's nouns, gog's blood, a pox, a plague, the devil take you, truce, truce, i smart, i smart.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha. O for one of the hoops of my Cornelius' tub: I must needs be gone, I shall burst myself with laughing else:
sp.l: Magic hath no such rule, men can not find,
Lust ever better handled in his kind.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: What art thou? with the name of Jove I conjure thee?

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: With any name saving the whip, I'll no more of that conjuration a plague on't.

sp.speaker: Gudg.
sp.p: Speak art not a spirit, in the likeness of my friend Lipsalve, that should transform thyself to mistress purge.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: How? A spirit? I hope spirits have no flesh and blood, and I am sure thou hast drawn blood out of my flesh with the spirit of thy whip.
Then shall we prove to be honest gulls, and the doctor an errant knave.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: A plague upon him for a glister . he has given our loves a suppositar with a recombentibus — I'll tell thee sirrah.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Tell not me, let me prevent thee, the wind shall not take the breath of our gross abuse, we feel the gullery: therefore let us swear by our naked truths, and by the hilts of these our blades, our flesh-tamers, to be revenged upon that paraperopandentical doctor, that pocky doctor.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Agreed, we'll cuckold him, that he shall not be able to put his head in at's doors, and make his precise puritanical, and peculiar punk his pothecaries drug there, a known cockatrice to the world.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.l: If report catch this knavery, we have lost our reputations for ever,
Wherefore let's be secret;
Ill tax we women of credulity,
When men are gulled with such gross foppery.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.l: Come let us in, and cover both our shames?
This conjuration to the world's a novelty,
Gallants turned spirits and whipped for lechery.

div.head: Act. 3. Scen. 4.
div.stage: Enter Maria and Gerardine out of the trunk.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Gerardine come forth Maria calls?
Those ribs shall not enfolded thy buxom limbs
One minute longer the cincture of mine arms
Shall more securely keep thy soul from harms.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: What heavenly breath of Phitonessae's power
(That raised the dead corpses of her friend to life)
Prevails no less on me, for even this urn
(The figure of my sadder requiem)
Gives up my bones, my love, my life, and all
To her, that gives me freedom in my thrall.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Be brief sweet friend, salute and part in one,
For niggard time now threats with imminent danger
Our late joyed scope: thy earnest then of love
Ere Sol have compassed half the signs I fear
Will show a blushing fault, but was thy plot, thine aim,
T'inforce consent in him that bars thy claim.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Love salves that fault, let time our guilt reveal,
I'll ne'er deny my deed, my hand, and seal.
The elements shall lose their ancient force;
Water and earth suppress the fire and air,
Nature in all use, a preposterous course,
Each kind forget his likeness to repair,
Before I'll falsify my faith to thee.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: The humorous bodies elemental kind,
Shall sooner lose th' innated heat of love,
The soul in nature's bounds shall be confined,
Heaven's course shall retrograde, and leave to move
Ere I surcease to cherish mutual fire,
With thoughts refined in flames of true desire.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: These words are odours in the sacred shrine
Of loves best deity: the marriage God
Longs to perform these ceremonious rites,
Which terminate our hopes; till mine grow full
I'll use that intercourse amongst my friends,
That erst I did: then in the height of joy,
I'll come to challenge interest in my boy.
Till then farewell.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: You'll come upon your cue

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Doubt not of that;

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Then twenty times adieu.

div.head: Actus quartus, scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Lypsalue and Guggin, Shrimp and periwinkle.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Come boys, our clothes boys, and what is the most currant news periwinkle.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.p: Faith sir, fortune hath favoured us with no news, but what the pedlar brought from Norfolk.

sp.speaker: Lyp.
sp.p: Is there nothing stirring at court shrimp?

sp.speaker: Shrim.
sp.p: Faith there is sir, but nothing new.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Good wag faith, thou smell'st somewhat of a courtier, though thy mother was a citizen's wife, off with that filthy great band, nay quick, on with your robe of sanctity; nay suddenly man.

sp.speaker: Gug.
sp.p: And why must we shift ourselves into this demure habit, if impossible to be of the family, and keep our own fashion.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Tut man the name of a gallant is more hateful to them, than the sight of a corner cap, hadst thou heard the protestations the wife of a bellowsmender made but yesternight, against gallants, thou hadst for ever abjured crimson breeches. She swore that all gallants, were persons inferior to bellowsmenders, for the trade of bellowsmaking was very aerial and high, and what were men and women but bellows, for they take wind in at one place, and do evaporate at another; evaporate was her very phrase.

sp.speaker: Guggin.
sp.p: methinks her phrase flew with somewhat too strong a vapour.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Nay she proves farther, that all men receive their being chiefly from bellows, without which the fire burns not, without fire the pot seethes not, the pot not seething, powdered beef is not to be eaten, of which she then averred our nation was a great devourer, and without which they could neither fight for their country abroad, nor get children at home: for said she, powdered beef is a great joiner of nerves together.

sp.speaker: Gug.
sp.p: What answer madest thou?

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: Marry, that I thought a bawd was a greater joiner of nerves together, then powdered beef, with that she protested, that a bawd was an instrument of the devil, and as she had proved that bellowsmakers were of God's trade, foe bawds were of the devil's trade: for (And thereupon she blew her nose) the devil and bawds did both live by the sins of the people.

sp.speaker: Gug.
sp.p: No more, mistress purge is at hand.

sp.speaker: Lyp.
sp.p:
Vanish boys, away, make haste, before Jove she'll be
with us ere we can be provided for her.

sp.speaker: Mi purge
sp.p: Advance your lynke club? At what time wert thou bound club? At Guttyde: Hollantide, or Candletide?

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: I was bound indeed about midsummer.

sp.speaker: Mistress Purge
sp.p: And when hath thy prenticeship end, at Michaeltide next?

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: So I take it.

sp.speaker: Mi purge
sp.p: They say club you fall very heavy on such you love not, you never learned that of me.

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: Indeed mistress I must confess, my falling is rustic gross, and butcherlike, marry yours is a pretty foolish light court take falling: yet believe me my master smells somewhat too gross of the purgation, he wants tutoring.

sp.speaker: Mi purge
sp.p: And why I pray?

sp.speaker: Club.
sp.p: My master being set last night in his shop, comes master doctor Glister (As his manner is) squirting in suddenly, and after some conference, tells my master that by his own knowledge you were young with child, to which my master replied, why master doctor, will you put me to more charges yet?

sp.speaker: Mi purge
sp.p: Thou art a fool, in that my husband spoke as wisely as if the master of his company had spoken , he knows doctors have receipts for women, which makes them most apt to conceive, and he promising 'a had ministered the same lately to me, thereupon spoke it, lead on with your link?

sp.speaker: Lipsa.
sp.p: Art ready?

sp.speaker: Gug.
sp.p: Ready.

sp.speaker: Lips.
sp.p: Then speak pitifully, look scurvily, and dissemble cunningly, and we shall quickly prove two of the fraternity benediction and sanctity; love and charity: fall on mistress purge, sister of the family.

sp.speaker: Mi purge
sp.p: And what I pray be you two?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Two newly converted from the rags of Christianity; to become good members in the house of the family.

sp.speaker: Mi purge
sp.p: Who I pray converted you?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Dry-fat the merchant.

sp.speaker: Mistress Purge
sp.p:
And from what sins hath he converted you?
From two very notorious crimes, the first was from eating fish on Fridays, and the second from speaking reverently of the clergy: but a resolved us, your talon in edifying young men went far beyond his.

sp.speaker: Ma. purge
sp.p: A talent I have therein, I must confess, nor am I very nice at fit times to show it; for your better instructions therefore, you must never hereafter frequent taverns nor tap-houses, no masks nor mummeries, no pastimes nor playhouses.

sp.speaker: Gud.
sp.p: Must we have no recreation?

sp.speaker: Mi purge
sp.p: Yes, on the days which profane lips call holidays, you may take your spaniel and spend some hours at the Duckingpond.

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: What are we bound unto, during the time we remain in the family.

sp.speaker: Mi purge
sp.p: During the light of the candle, you are to be very attentive, which being extinguished, how to behave yourselves, I will deliver in private whisper.

sp.speaker: Ma. purge
sp.p: 'Tis now come to a whisper, what young Familists be these? i'faith I'll make one, I'll trip you wife, I sent your footing wife.
sp.l: For Gallus writes, Paraselsus can tell,
Pothecaries have brains, and noses eke to smell,

sp.speaker: Lip.
sp.p: We shall with much diligence observe it.

sp.speaker: Ma. purge
sp.p: I fear I shall have small cause to thank that diligence, but do your worst, he that hath red fine hairballs in one year, can find a trick which shall prevent this gear, they are going, follow purge, close, close and softly, like a horsekeeper in a lady's matted chamber at midnight.

div.stage: Exeunt Gudgin, Lipsalve, and mistress Purge.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Who knocks?

sp.speaker: Mi purge
sp.p: Brethren and a sister in the family.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Enter in peace.

sp.speaker: Ma. purge.
sp.p: Brethren and a sister, that's the word, how beastly was I mistaken last day, i should have said a brother in the family — and I said a familiar brother, for which i and my family were thrust out of doors: but as Titus Silus of Holborn bridge most learnedly was wont to say, quoth —

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Ma. pu.
sp.p: A brother in the family.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Enter, and welcome.

div.head: Act. 4. Scaena. 2.
div.l: Thou sacred deity, love:
Thou power predominate, more to be admired,
Then able to be expressed, whose orb includes
All terrene joys which are, all states which be,
Pay to thy sacred throne, as tribute fee
Their thoughts and lives like Jove's so must thy acts
Endure no question, why, thy hidden facts,
The gods themselves obey, heaven Synod holds,
No gods, but what thy awful power controls,
The Delphian archer proud with Python's spoil
At Cupid's hand was forced to take the foil:
Not Mars his warlike adamantine targe,
Could free his warlike breast at Cupid's charge;
And Jove whose frown all mortal lives bereaves
This marble throne and ivory sceptre leaves:
And in the likeness of a bull was seen,
As forced by him to bear the Tyrian Queen:
Through Neptune's watery kingdom, if these submit
My Metamorphos is not held unfit:
div.p: And see in most wished occasion Drifat the merchant presents himself: sir, in the best of hours met, my thoughts had marked you out for a man most apt, to do them the fairest of offices.

sp.speaker: Dri.
sp.p: What? art thou a Welsh carrier, or a Northern landlord, thou'rt so saucy.

sp.speaker: Gera.
sp.p: Is't possible sir, my disguise should so much fool your knowledge? how, a Northern landlord? can you think i get my living by a bell and a Clackdish?

sp.speaker: Dri.
sp.p: By a bell and a Clackdish, how's that?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Why by begging sir, know you me now?

sp.speaker: Dri.
sp.p: Ma. Gerardine, disguised and ashore, nay then i smell a rat.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Master dry-fat, shall I repose some trust in you, will you lay by a while your city's precise humour, will you not deceive me?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: If I deceive your trust, the general plague seize me, that is, may I die a cuckold.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: And I say thou shall die a true citizen, if thou conceal it: and thus in brief, it stands with thy knowledge how seriously I have (And do still affect Maria: now sir, I have so wrought it, that if thou couldst procure me a fellow, that could serve in stead of a crier, I myself would play placket the parritor, and summon doctor Glister and Maria to appear at thy house, and as he plays the parritor, so wouldst thou but assume the shape of a proctor, I should have the wench, thou the credit, and the whole city occasion of discourse this nine days.

sp.speaker: Dri.
sp.p: How's this, how's this! I should procure a fellow to play the parritor, and I myself should play the proctor: but upon what occasion should they be summoned?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Upon an accusation, that doctor Glister should get Maria his niece with child, and have bastards in the country which I have a trick to make probable.

sp.speaker: Dri.
sp.p: And now I recall it to memory, I heard somewhat to that effect last night, in master Beardbush the barber's shop, but how will this sort, who shall accuse him?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Refer that to me, I say, be that my care, all shall end in merriment, and no disgrace touch either of their reputations.

sp.speaker: Dri.
sp.p: Then take both word and hand, 'tis done, club (Mistress purges prentice) shall be the sumner.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: O my most precious dry-fat, may none of thy daughters prove vessels with foul bungholes, or none of thy sons hogsheads, but all true and honourable dryfats like thyself.

sp.speaker: Dri.
sp.p: Well master Gerardine, I hope to see you a Familist before I die.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: That's most likely, for i hold most of their principles already: I never rail nor calumniate any man, but in love and charity; I never cozen any man for any ill will I bear him, but in love and charity to myself: I never make my neighbour a cuckold for any hate or malice I bear him, but in love and charity to his wife.

sp.speaker: Dri.
sp.p: And may those principles fructify in your weak members: I'll be gone, and with most quick dexterity provide you a crier: tomorrow at my house (Said you) they should appear.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Be that the time, most honoured dry-fat, but be this known to none, most loved sir, save club, or to some other whom your judgement shall select, as a fit person for our project.

sp.speaker: Dri.
sp.p: Thus enough time out of sight.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Maria, thou art mine: earth's affection and nature's glory, woman of what an excellency, if her thoughts and acts were squared and levelled with the first celsitude of her creation:
sp.l: T'enjoy a creature, whose dishevelled locks,
Like gems against the repercussive sun,
Gives light and splendour . whose starlike eyes
Attract more gazar loves to see them move
Then the Tartarians god, when first egeons hill
Amounts in triumph, a skin more pure and soft,
Then is the silkworm bed, to the more white
Then newfallen snow, or shining ivory,
Is happiness sought by the gods themselves,
Celestial Venus born without a mother,
Be thou probitious, thee and I implore
Not vulgar Venus, heaven's scorn and Mars his whore.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Good aunt quiet yourself, ground not upon dreams, you know they are ever contrary.

sp.speaker: Mi Gli.
sp.p:
Minion, minion, coin no excuses; I grant dreams are deceitful, but a true judgement grounded upon knowledge never fails: what? have not I observed the rising and
falling of the blood, the coming and going of the countenance, your qualms, your unlacings, your longings, most evident tokens, besides a more certain sign then all these too, you know't, I need not speak it; nay I am as skilful in that point as my husband: I can tell you Aristotle speaks English enough to tell me these secrets: body of me, so narrowly looked too, and yet fly out? well, I see maids will have't, in spite of laws or locks that restrain 'em, they will open, do men what they can.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I see my fault appears, simplicity
Hath no evasion: 'tis bootless to deny,
Where guilty blood, cited by touch of shame,
Runs through my veins, and leaves my conscience stain,
Even in my face for bear I do beseech you,
To publish my defame, what I have done,
You shall not answer, I must bear mine own.

sp.speaker: Mi Gli.
sp.p: Bear your own? I marry there it goes, what must you bear?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: My sins forsooth.

sp.speaker: Mi Gli.
sp.p: Your sins forsooth: confess to me, and go not about the bush, you have been doing that's flat, you have caught a clap, that's round, and answer me roundly to the point, or else I'll square. Come whose act is't? I can not devise unless it be my husbands, for none else had access to thee; i am sure time has turned his bald side to thee, and I do but wonder how thou tookst opportunity: speak, tell me.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Now good aunt press me not, let time reveal
What you suspect, for never shall my tongue
Confess an act that tends unto my wrong.

sp.speaker: Mi Gli.
sp.p: Will you not boult, I must have't out on you, and will.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: By your leave mistress.

sp.speaker: Mi Gli.
sp.p: Passion of my heart, what art thou?

sp.speaker: Ger
sp.p: No ghost forsooth, though I appear in white.

sp.speaker: Mi Gli.
sp.p: No, but a saucy knave i perceive by your manners.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p:
None of that livery neither: I am of the bearing trade forsooth, you may see by my smock — frock I would say: I am (If it please you) of the spick and span new set up company of porters,
here's my breast plate, and besides our own arms we have the arms of the city to help us in our burdens, ecce signum: here's the cross, and the sword of justice in good pewter, i can tell you which goes as currant with us as better mettle.

sp.speaker: Mi Gli.
sp.p: What's your name sir?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Nicholas Nebulo there's but a straw's breadth between that and the arms, 'tis in the back side of the cross here, and well known in the city for an ancient name, and an honest an't like your worship.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You are none of the 12 are you?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: No forsooth but one of the 24.

sp.speaker: Mi Gli.
sp.p: Order of knaves, I thought so, sirrah you're a rascal to come thus bluntly into my house with your dirty startups, get you without doors like a filthy fellow as you are, a place more fit for you.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: O good words mistress; I may be warden of my company for ought you know and for my bluntness we have a clause in our charter to warrant that for as we bear, so likewise we may be born with, and have free egress and regress where our business lies.

sp.speaker: Mi Gli.
sp.p: And what's your business here?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I have a letter an't please you to master doctor.

sp.speaker: Mi Gli.
sp.p: From whence?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: That I cannot show your worship, but I had it of Curtal the carrier whose lawful deputy I am.

sp.speaker: Mi Gli.
sp.p: Leave your scraping sirrah: fie how rank the knave smells of grease and tapsdroppings.

sp.speaker: Ger.
